metadata.unitName: TEST orange Forces Shape Earth's Surface

generationDetails.description: Each lesson generated as many valid questions as possible

questions.question: Which layer forms Earth’s outermost, rocky shell?

answers.explanation: The crust is the thin, solid, outermost layer on which we live.

questions.question: Which description best matches Earth’s mantle?

answers.content: A shell of solid iron and nickel under great pressure
A layer of semi-solid, slowly moving rock that becomes hotter with depth
answers.explanation: Convection currents in this semi-solid rock drive many surface changes.

answers.content: A thin, brittle layer of broken rock plates
A liquid layer of metallic iron and nickel creating Earth’s magnetic field

questions.question: Which layer of Earth is liquid and made mostly of molten iron and nickel?

answers.explanation: Seismic data show the outer core does not transmit S-waves, indicating it is liquid.

questions.question: Despite temperatures similar to the Sun’s surface, the inner core remains solid because

answers.content: it is made of rock instead of metal
extreme pressure prevents the atoms from moving into a liquid state
answers.explanation: Immense pressure at Earth’s centre keeps the iron–nickel alloy solid.

answers.content: it is cooler than the mantle
it contains large amounts of water

questions.question: List the four main layers of Earth in order starting at the surface.

answers.content: Crust, Mantle, Outer core, Inner core

questions.question: Which of Earth’s layers is the thickest?

answers.explanation: The mantle is about 2 900 km thick—far thicker than any other layer.

questions.question: Draw and label a cross-section diagram of Earth showing the crust, mantle, outer core and inner core. Add one short annotation for each layer describing its composition or state.

answers.content: Diagram shows all four layers in correct order (1 mark); each layer clearly labelled (1 mark); annotations accurately describe composition/state, e.g. “solid rock”, “semi-solid”, “liquid iron–nickel”, “solid iron–nickel” (1 mark).

questions.question: What part of Earth’s crust includes the seafloor?
During the playdough activity, which colour of playdough represented the thinnest layer?

answers.content: The colour used for the crust
answers.explanation: Students rolled the final, thinnest sheet of playdough to model the crust.

answers.content: The colour used for the mantle
The colour used for the outer core
The colour used for the inner core

questions.question: What is the main cause of an earthquake?

answers.content: The sudden movement of tectonic plates that have been stuck together
answers.explanation: Stress builds along plate boundaries until the plates suddenly slip, releasing energy as an earthquake.
Subsidence happens slowly and does not create earthquake-like shaking.

answers.content: The Moon’s gravitational pull on the oceans
answers.explanation: Tides are caused by the Moon, but they do not generate earthquakes.

questions.question: During the Mars-bar model, which part of the chocolate bar represents Earth’s crust?

answers.explanation: The brittle outer shell of the Mars bar is like the rigid lithospheric crust.
The caramel better models the softer asthenosphere beneath the crust.
The whole bar is the whole Earth in the model, but the question asks for the crust specifically.

questions.question: Why does Australia experience comparatively few large earthquakes?

answers.content: Because Australia lies in the centre of a tectonic plate
answers.explanation: Plate interiors are usually far from active plate boundaries where most earthquakes occur.

answers.content: Because Australia lies on the equator
answers.explanation: Latitude has no influence on earthquake frequency.

answers.content: Because Australia is a very large continent
answers.explanation: Size alone does not affect earthquake activity.

questions.question: In the opening earthquake-location animation, the bright purple flashes mainly represent:

answers.content: Epicentres that generated tsunamis in the ocean
answers.explanation: Purple highlights mark under-sea quakes whose energy produced tsunamis.
Volcanic events were not shown in this animation.
Meteorite impacts were not part of the data visualised.

questions.question: Which of the following was a reported change to the Noto Peninsula landscape after the 2024 earthquake?

answers.content: Sections of coastline lifted upward out of the sea
answers.explanation: Parts of the shoreline were thrust upward, exposing new land.

answers.content: A large new freshwater lake formed in the interior
answers.explanation: The article did not mention formation of a new lake.
No reference was made to mountain ice melt.

questions.question:
Complete the sentence using the causal connective ‘so’.
“The earthquake struck ___.”

answers.content: so the land rose up, changing the shape of the coastline
answers.explanation: Answers must link the cause (earthquake) to an effect on the landscape using the connective ‘so’.

questions.question: Define the term ‘landscape’ as it is used in this lesson.

answers.content: Any natural or built features that make up an area of Earth’s surface
answers.explanation: Landscape includes both natural landforms and human-made structures found in one place.

questions.question: Draw and label a diagram that shows how an under-sea earthquake can create a tsunami that travels toward land.

answers.content: Student diagram should illustrate: sea-floor fault movement, upward displacement of water, series of waves moving toward coast, and eventual impact on shoreline.
answers.explanation: Look for key labelled features: earthquake focus/epicentre, uplift/subsidence, wave fronts, coastline.

questions.question: Which word describes molten rock after it reaches Earth’s surface during an eruption?

answers.explanation: Magma is the molten rock while it is still below Earth’s surface.
Once magma breaks through the surface it is called lava.
Ash is fine-grained volcanic rock blasted into the air.
The crust is Earth’s outer solid layer.

questions.question: Give ONE constructive (positive) way a volcanic eruption can change the landscape.

answers.content: Volcanic eruptions can create new land that eventually becomes fertile soil for plants.

questions.question: During the volcano model activity, which liquid is poured into the jar to start the ‘eruption’?

answers.explanation: Vinegar reacts with the baking soda to produce carbon-dioxide bubbles that simulate flowing lava.

questions.question: Draw and label a diagram that shows: (a) the immediate change to a landscape caused by a volcanic eruption, and (b) one knock-on effect of that change. Use arrows and causal connectives to make the relationship clear.

answers.content: Expected features: labelled volcano releasing lava/ash; new land or ash layer shown; arrow to a knock-on effect such as ‘fertile soil helps plants grow’ or ‘buried homes force people to move’; inclusion of a causal connective such as ‘because’ or ‘therefore’.

questions.question: Mount Vesuvius buried the city of Pompeii in which year?

answers.explanation: Historical records show the catastrophic eruption occurred in 79 AD.

questions.question: Explain how the movement of tectonic plates is related to the formation of most volcanoes.

answers.content: Most volcanoes form at plate boundaries where plates move apart or collide, creating cracks that allow magma to rise to the surface.

questions.question: Which causal connective best introduces a knock-on effect in a sentence?

answers.explanation: ‘Because’ explicitly links a cause to its effect.

questions.question: What is the scientific term for the process that breaks rocks into smaller pieces without transporting them?

answers.explanation: Erosion involves transporting weathered material.
Deposition is the laying down of sediment.
Weathering is the breakdown of rocks in place.
Melting changes state, not rock breakdown.

questions.question: Which of the following was NOT identified in the lesson as an agent of weathering?

answers.explanation: Wind was explored as an agent.
Water was explored as an agent.
Plants were explored as an agent.
Electricity was not discussed as an agent of weathering.

questions.question: In the model paragraph about moving water, which causal connective appears that students had NOT studied in earlier lessons?

answers.explanation: "so" was already known.
"as a result" was already known.
"due to" is the new connective.
"because" did not appear in the paragraph.

questions.question: Describe, in one or two sentences, how moving water can weather rocks. Use at least one causal connective in your explanation.

answers.content: Flowing rivers, ocean waves and heavy rain carry sand and other particles that repeatedly strike rock surfaces, so the rocks slowly wear away and become smoother.

questions.question: Explain how plant roots contribute to the weathering of rocks. Include what happens as the roots grow.

answers.content: As a seedling’s roots grow into cracks in a rock, they exert pressure on the crack walls; over time the roots thicken and push the rock apart, causing it to fracture and break into smaller pieces.

questions.question: Draw a simple flow-chart or sequence diagram that shows how wind weathers a large angular rock into smooth pebbles. Label each stage with a phrase and include at least two causal connectives (for example, ‘because’, ‘therefore’).

answers.content:
5 marks – Diagram has 4 or more clearly labelled stages, two correct causal connectives, clear arrows showing sequence, and accurate explanation of abrasion by wind-blown sand.
3–4 marks – 3 stages, one connective, generally accurate science.
1–2 marks – Minimal stages or scientific inaccuracies.
0 marks – No relevant diagram.

questions.question: What is the BEST definition of erosion?

answers.content: The breaking of rocks into smaller pieces on Earth’s surface.
answers.explanation: This describes weathering, not erosion.

answers.content: The movement of rocks, soil and sand to another place.
answers.explanation: Erosion involves transporting weathered material elsewhere.

answers.content: The cooling of molten rock beneath Earth’s surface.
answers.explanation: This describes igneous rock formation, unrelated to erosion.

answers.content: The dropping of sediment in a new location.
answers.explanation: This is deposition, which follows erosion.

questions.question: In the class investigation, which variable was CHANGED to test its effect on erosion?

answers.content: Amount of water poured into the tray
answers.explanation: The same cup of water was used each time.
The same damp sand was used in every tray.
Only the slope was varied (flat, gentle, steep).

answers.content: Length of the ‘river’ drawn in the sand
answers.explanation: The river length stayed the same in all trays.

questions.question: Why does faster-moving water cause more erosion?

answers.content: Fast water has less energy and therefore removes more sand.
answers.explanation: Less energy cannot remove more sediment.

answers.content: Fast water has greater force and can pick up and carry more sediment.
answers.explanation: Greater speed = greater kinetic energy = more force to lift and move particles.

answers.content: Fast water increases weathering but not erosion.
answers.explanation: The investigation focused on erosion, not weathering.

answers.content: Fast water makes the sand heavier so it rolls downhill.
answers.explanation: Water speed doesn’t change sand mass.

questions.question: A student set up the three trays but accidentally poured twice as much water into tray 3 as into trays 1 and 2.  How would this mistake MOST LIKELY affect the fairness of the test?

answers.content: It would not affect fairness because slope angle is still different.
answers.explanation: Changing more than one variable makes the test unfair.

answers.content: It would make the test unfair because two variables (slope and water volume) changed.
answers.explanation: Only one variable should change in a fair test.

answers.content: It would improve fairness by increasing reliability of results.
answers.explanation: Introducing an extra variable decreases reliability.

answers.content: It would have no effect because water drains out of the tray anyway.
answers.explanation: Different water volumes still influence erosion amount.

questions.question: Which real-world example is MOST directly created by water erosion?

answers.explanation: Formed mainly by wind erosion.
Coastal waves erode cliff rock leaving isolated stacks.

answers.content: Sand dunes in the Sahara Desert
answers.explanation: Predominantly wind-driven.
Result of uplift and long-term weathering, not primarily water erosion.

questions.question: Explain, using scientific vocabulary, the relationship between weathering, erosion and deposition.

answers.content: Weathering breaks down rock into smaller particles.  Erosion then transports those particles to a new place using agents such as moving water, wind or ice.  Deposition occurs when the moving agent loses energy and drops the transported sediment, forming new landforms.

questions.question: A river flowing through a steep mountain valley suddenly enters a wide, flat plain.  Predict what will happen to the sediment load and explain why.

answers.content: When the river reaches the flat plain its speed decreases, so it loses energy and can no longer carry as much sediment.  Much of the sediment will be deposited, forming features like alluvial fans or floodplains.

questions.question:
Draw and label a diagram of the class tray experiment showing:
• the three different slopes
• the direction of water flow
• areas where the greatest amount of sand collected after erosion.

answers.content: Student provides labelled diagram clearly indicating slope angles, flow arrows and deposition zones.
